newsitem.title: IRAQ: Jordan to buy 4.5 mln tonnes of Iraqi oil in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Jordan to buy 4.5 mln tonnes of Iraqi oil in 1997.

text.p: Jordan will buy 4.5 million tonnes of crude oil and refined oil products from Iraq in 1997, a senior Jordanian official said on Monday.
"...All together between crude oil and by-products, (we are buying) 4.5 million tonnes (for 1997)," Jordanian Energy and Mineral Resources Minister Hashem Dabbas told Reuters.
Dabbas, heading a high-ranking Jordanian trade team to Baghdad including Finance and Customs Minister Marwan Awad, arrived in Baghdad late on Sunday.

Last year Jordan agreed with Iraq to buy oil estimated at 4.4 million tonnes -- an amount exempt from the United Nations trade sanctions that bar Iraq from exporting its oil following its 1990 invasion of Kuwait.
The Jordanian minister said this year's oil imports from Iraq would be more than last year's with "seven percent increase rate."
Iraqi crude to Jordan is trucked by a fleet of about 2,000 tankers and Jordan imports 75,000 barrels per day (bpd) from Iraq.
Amman pays market prices for 25,000 bpd and for another 25,000 bpd of products. The rest is at undisclosed concessionary terms.
